revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} '''Green computing''', '''green ICT''' as per International Federation of Global & Green ICT "IFGICT", '''green IT''', or '''ICT sustainability''', is the study and practice of [[environmentally sustainable]] computing or IT.
The goals of green computing are similar to [[green chemistry]]: reduce the use of hazardous materials, maximize [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] during the product's lifetime, the [[recycling|recyclability]] or [[Biodegradation|biodegradability]] of defunct products and factory waste. Green computing is important for all classes of systems, ranging from handheld systems<ref>S. Mittal, "[https://www.academia.edu/4186102/A_survey_of_techniques_for_improving_energy_efficiency_in_embedded_computing_systems A survey of techniques for improving energy efficiency in embedded computing systems] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004011859/http://www.academia.edu/4186102/A_survey_of_techniques_for_improving_energy_efficiency_in_embedded_computing_systems |date=October 4, 2015 }}", IJCAET, 6(4), 440–459, 2014.</ref> to large-scale data centers.<ref name="ReferenceGCS9"/>
Many corporate IT departments have green computing initiatives to reduce the environmental effect of their IT operations.<ref>E. Curry, B. Guyon, C. Sheridan, and B. Donnellan, [http://www.edwardcurry.org/publications/MISQE_SustainableIT_Intel_2012.pdf “Developing a Sustainable IT Capability: Lessons From Intel’s Journey,”] ''[[MIS Quarterly Executive]]'', vol. 11, no. 2, pp. 61–74, 2012.</ref> {{TOC limit}}
[[File:Energy Star logo.svg|thumb|right|Energy Star logo|100px]] In 1992, the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] launched [[Energy Star]], a voluntary labeling program that is designed to promote and recognize the [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] in monitors, climate control equipment, and other technologies. This resulted in the widespread adoption of [[sleep mode]] among consumer electronics. Concurrently, the Swedish organization TCO Development launched the [[TCO Certification]] program to promote low magnetic and electrical emissions from [[Cathode ray tube|CRT]]-based [[computer display]]s; this program was later expanded to include criteria on energy consumption, [[ergonomics]], and the use of hazardous materials in construction.<ref>{{cite news |title=TCO takes the initiative in comparative product testing |accessdate=May 3, 2008 |date=May 3, 2008 |url=http://www.boivie.se/index.php?page=2&lang=eng |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070723060821/http://www.boivie.se/index.php?page=2&lang=eng |archive-date=July 23, 2007 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Regulations and industry initiatives== The [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) has published a survey of over 90 government and industry initiatives on "Green ICTs", i.e. information and communication technologies, the environment and climate change. The report concludes that initiatives tend to concentrate on the greening ICTs themselves rather than on their actual implementation to tackle global warming and environmental degradation. In general, only 20% of initiatives have measurable targets, with government programs tending to include targets more frequently than business associations.<ref>Full report: {{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/47/12/42825130.pdf|author=OECD Working Party on the Information Economy|title=Towards Green ICT strategies: Assessing Policies and Programmes on ICTs and the Environment|access-date=November 22, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317103746/http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/47/12/42825130.pdf|archive-date=March 17, 2012|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Summary: {{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/46/18/43044065.pdf|title=Executive summary of OECD report|author=OECD Working Party on the Information Economy|access-date=November 22, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317102750/http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/46/18/43044065.pdf|archive-date=March 17, 2012|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Government=== Many [[governmental]] agencies have continued to implement standards and regulations that encourage green computing. The [[Energy Star]] program was revised in October 2006 to include stricter efficiency requirements for computer equipment, along with a tiered ranking system for approved products.<ref>{{cite web |title=EPA Announces New Computer Efficiency Requirements |date=October 23, 2006 |url=http://yosemite.epa.gov/opa/admpress.nsf/a8f952395381d3968525701c005e65b5/113b0c0647fee41585257210006474f1!OpenDocument |last=Jones |first=Ernesta |publisher=U.S. EPA |accessdate=September 18, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212022429/http://yosemite.epa.gov/opa/admpress.nsf/a8f952395381d3968525701c005e65b5/113b0c0647fee41585257210006474f1!OpenDocument |archive-date=February 12, 2007 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1759,2097558,00.asp |title=How Important Will New Energy Star Be for PC Makers? |last=Gardiner |first=Bryan |date=February 22, 2007 |publisher=PC Magazine |accessdate=September 18, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070826193654/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1759,2097558,00.asp |archive-date=August 26, 2007 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
By 2008, 26 US states established statewide recycling programs for obsolete computers and consumer electronics equipment.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.e-takeback.org/docs%20open/Toolkit_Legislators/state%20legislation/state_leg_main.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306222713/http://www.e-takeback.org/docs%20open/Toolkit_Legislators/state%20legislation/state_leg_main.htm |archivedate=March 6, 2009 |title= State Legislation on E-Waste |date=March 20, 2008 |publisher=Electronics Take Back Coalition |accessdate=March 8, 2008 }}</ref> The statutes either impose an "advance recovery fee" for each unit sold at retail or require the manufacturers to reclaim the equipment at disposal.
In 2010, the [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act]] (ARRA) was signed into legislation by President Obama. The bill allocated over $90 billion to be invested in green initiatives (renewable energy, smart grids, energy efficiency, etc.) In January 2010, the U.S. Energy Department granted $47 million of the ARRA money towards projects that aim to improve the energy efficiency of data centers. The projects provided research to optimize data center hardware and software, improve power supply chain, and [[computer cooling|data center cooling technologies]].<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.energy.gov/news2009/8491.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527141406/http://www.energy.gov/news2009/8491.htm |archivedate=May 27, 2010 |title=Secretary Chu Announces $47 Million to Improve Efficiency in Information Technology and Communications Sectors |publisher=U.S. Department of Energy |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=October 30, 2010}}</ref>
===Industry=== * [[Climate Savers Computing Initiative]] (CSCI) is an effort to reduce the electric power consumption of PCs in active and inactive states.<ref name="CSCI_pressrel_launch">{{Cite press release |url=http://www.climatesaverscomputing.org/program/press.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214140754/http://www.climatesaverscomputing.org/program/press.html |archivedate=February 14, 2008 |title=Intel and Google Join with Dell, EDS, EPA, HP, IBM, Lenovo, Microsoft, PG&E, World Wildlife Fund and Others to Launch Climate Savers Computing Initiative |publisher=Business Wire |date=June 12, 2007 |accessdate=December 11, 2007}}</ref> The CSCI provides a catalog of green products from its member organizations, and information for reducing PC power consumption. It was started on 2007-06-12. The name stems from the [[World Wildlife Fund]]'s Climate Savers program, which was launched in 1999.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.climatesaverscomputing.org/program/index.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215151042/http://www.climatesaverscomputing.org/program/index.html |archivedate=December 15, 2007 |title=What exactly is the Climate Savers Computing Initiative? |publisher=Climate Savers Computing Initiative |year=2007 |accessdate=December 11, 2007}}</ref> The WWF is also a member of the Computing Initiative.<ref name="CSCI_pressrel_launch" /> * The [[Green Electronics Council]] offers the [[Electronic Product Environmental Assessment Tool]] (EPEAT) to assist in the purchase of "greener" computing systems. The Council evaluates computing equipment on 51 criteria - 23 required and 28 optional - that measure a product's efficiency and sustainability attributes. Products are rated Gold, Silver, or Bronze, depending on how many optional criteria they meet. On 2007-01-24, President [[George W. Bush]] issued Executive Order 13423, which requires all United States Federal agencies to use EPEAT when purchasing computer systems.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.epeat.net/Docs/Bush%20Requires%20EPEAT%20(1-24-07).pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5qCuJd6am?url=http://www.epeat.net/Docs/Bush%20Requires%20EPEAT%20%281-24-07%29.pdf |archivedate=June 3, 2010 |title=President Bush Requires Federal Agencies to Buy EPEAT Registered Green Electronic Products |publisher=Green Electronics Council |date=January 24, 2007 |accessdate=September 20, 2007 |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/01/20070124-2.html |title=Executive Order: Strengthening Federal Environmental, Energy, and Transportation Management |publisher=The White House: Office of the Press Secretary |date=January 24, 2007 |accessdate=September 20, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831005045/http://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/01/20070124-2.html |archive-date=August 31, 2011 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[The Green Grid]] is a global consortium dedicated to advancing energy efficiency in data centers and business computing ecosystems. It was founded in February 2007 by several key companies in the industry – [[AMD]], [[American Power Conversion|APC]], [[Dell]], [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]], [[IBM]], [[Intel]], [[Microsoft]], [[Rackable Systems]], [[SprayCool]] (purchased in 2010 by [http://www.parker.com/portal/site/Market-Tech/menuitem.e9f921bc8ae21676de92b210237ad1ca/?vgnextoid=e7bfa7bee4a70310VgnVCM10000048021dacRCRD&vgnextfmt=default Parker]), [[Sun Microsystems]] and [[VMware]]. The Green Grid has since grown to hundreds of members, including end-users and government organizations, all focused on improving [[data center infrastructure efficiency]] (DCIE). * The [[Green500]] list rates supercomputers by energy efficiency ([[megaflops]]/[[watt]]), encouraging a focus on efficiency rather than absolute performance. * [[Green Comm Challenge]] is an organization that promotes the development of energy conservation technology and practices in the field of Information and Communications Technology (ICT). * The [[Transaction Processing Performance Council]] (TPC) Energy specification augments existing TPC benchmarks by allowing optional publications of energy metrics alongside performance results.<ref>{{cite web |title= Energy benchmarks: a detailed analysis (e-Energy 2006) |url=http://portal.acm.org/citation.cfm?doid=1791314.1791336|publisher=ACM. {{ISBN|978-1-4503-0042-1}}. Meikel Poess, Raghunath Nambiar, Kushagra Vaid, John M. Stephens, Jr., Karl Huppler, Evan Haines }}</ref> * [[SPECpower]] is the first industry standard benchmark that measures power consumption in relation to performance for server-class computers. Other benchmarks which measure energy efficiency include [[SPECweb]], [[SPECvirt]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spec.org/power/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412195835/http://www.spec.org/power/ |archivedate=April 12, 2013 |title=SPEC Power and Performance Committee |publisher=SPEC |year=2013 |accessdate=May 15, 2013}}</ref> and [[VMmark]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vmmark.com |title=www.vmmark.com |publisher=VMware |year=2013 |accessdate=May 15, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430182231/http://www.vmmark.com/ |archive-date=April 30, 2013 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Approaches== Modern [[Information technology|IT]] systems rely upon a complicated mix of people, networks, and hardware; as such, a green computing initiative must cover all of these areas as well. A solution may also need to address end user satisfaction, management restructuring, regulatory compliance, and return on investment (ROI). There are also considerable fiscal motivations for companies to take control of their own power consumption; "of the power management tools available, one of the most powerful may still be simple, plain, common sense."<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.deloitte.co.uk/TMTPredictions/technology/Green-and-lean-it-data-centre-efficiency.cfm |archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20100706131340/http://www.deloitte.co.uk/TMTPredictions/technology/Green-and-lean-it-data-centre-efficiency.cfm |archivedate =July 6, 2010 |title=The common sense of lean and green IT |work=Deloitte Technology Predictions}}</ref>
===Product longevity=== [[Gartner]] maintains that the PC manufacturing process accounts for 70% of the natural resources used in the life cycle of a PC.<ref>InfoWorld July 6, 2009; {{cite web |url=http://www.infoworld.com/d/green-it/used-pc-strategy-passes-toxic-buck-300?_kip_ipx=1053322433-1267784052&_pxn=0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120121223HCFSDBIFBWETHVYUSDVFSDJB CFSDBVGZDGFCHGSDVYUFSDYVGASJDVG315/http://www.infoworld.com/d/green-it/used-pc-strategy-passes-toxic-buck-300?_kip_ipx=1053322433-1267784052&_pxn=0 |archivedate=January 21, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> More recently, Fujitsu released a Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of a desktop that show that manufacturing and end of life accounts for the majority of this desktop's ecological footprint.<ref>GreenIT.fr Feb. 2011; http://www.greenit.fr/article/materiel/pc-de-bureau/quelle-est-l-empreinte-carbone-d-un-ordinateur-3478 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110424020904/http://www.greenit.fr/article/materiel/pc-de-bureau/quelle-est-l-empreinte-carbone-d-un-ordinateur-3478 |date=April 24, 2011 }}</ref> Therefore, the biggest contribution to green computing usually is to prolong the equipment's lifetime. Another report from Gartner recommends to "Look for product longevity, including upgradability and modularity."<ref>Simon Mingay, Gartner: 10 Key Elements of a 'Green IT' Strategy; {{cite web |url=http://www.onsitelasermedic.com/pdf/10_key_elements_greenIT.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730120749/http://www.onsitelasermedic.com/pdf/10_key_elements_greenIT.pdf |archivedate=July 30, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}.</ref> For instance, manufacturing a new PC makes a far bigger [[ecological footprint]] than manufacturing a new [[RAM]] module to upgrade an existing one.
===Data center design=== Data center facilities are heavy consumers of energy, accounting for between 1.1% and 1.5% of the world’s total energy use in 2010 [1]. The U.S. Department of Energy estimates that data center facilities consume up to 100 to 200 times more energy than standard office buildings.<ref name="https://energy.gov">“Best Practices Guide for Energy-Efficient Data Center Design”, prepared by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory for the U.S. Department of Energy, Federal Energy Management Program, March 2011.[https://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/10/f3/eedatacenterbestpractices.pdf] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220151305/https://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/10/f3/eedatacenterbestpractices.pdf |date=December 20, 2016 }}</ref>
Energy efficient data center design should address all of the energy use aspects included in a data center: from the IT equipment to the HVAC(Heating, ventilation and air conditioning) equipment to the actual location, configuration and construction of the building.
The U.S. Department of Energy specifies five primary areas on which to focus energy efficient data center design best practices:<ref>Koomey, Jonathon. “Growth in data center electricity use 2005 to 2010,” Oakland, CA: Analytics Press. August 1. {{cite web |url=http://www.analyticspress.com/datacenters.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111082558/http://www.analyticspress.com/datacenters.html |archivedate=January 11, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
* Information technology (IT) systems * Environmental conditions * Air management * Cooling systems * Electrical systems
Additional energy efficient design opportunities specified by the U.S. Department of Energy include on-site electrical generation and recycling of waste heat.<ref>Junaid Shuja, Abdullah Gani, Shahaboddin Shamshirband, Raja Wasim Ahmad, Kashif Bilal, Sustainable Cloud Data Centers: A survey of enabling techniques and technologies, Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews, Volume 62, September 2016, Pages 195-214, ISSN 1364-0321, https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.rser.2016.04.034</ref>
Energy efficient data center design should help to better utilize a data center’s space, and increase performance and efficiency.
In 2018, three new US Patents make use of facilities design to simultaneously cool and produce electrical power by use of internal and external waste heat. The three patents use silo design for stimulating use internal waste heat, while the recirculation of the air cooling the silo's computing racks. US Patent [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=4&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=matteo&s2=gravina&OS=matteo+AND+gravina&RS=matteo+AND+gravina 9,510,486], uses the recirculating air for power generation, while sister patent, US Patent [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=2&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=matteo&s2=gravina&OS=matteo+AND+gravina&RS=matteo+AND+gravina 9,907,213], forces the recirculation of the same air, and sister patent, US Patent [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=matteo&s2=gravina&OS=matteo+AND+gravina&RS=matteo+AND+gravina 10,020,436], uses thermal differences in temperature resulting in negative power usage effectiveness. Negative power usage effectiveness, makes use of extreme differences between temperatures at times running the computing facilities, that they would run only from external sources other than the power use for computing.
===Software and deployment optimization===
====Algorithmic efficiency==== {{Main article|Algorithmic efficiency}} {{Further|Analysis of algorithms}} The efficiency of algorithms affects the amount of computer resources required for any given computing function and there are many efficiency trade-offs in writing programs. Algorithm changes, such as switching from a slow (e.g. linear) search algorithm to a fast (e.g. hashed or indexed) search algorithm can reduce resource usage for a given task from substantial to close to zero. <!-- algorithmic efficiency personal example: I re-coded a SQL report query (that was run several times a day) that took 30 minutes to run in 15 seconds. Impressive? Sure! Unusual? Hardly. I'm sure there are citeable examples.--> In 2009, a study by a physicist at [[Harvard]] estimated that the average Google search released 7 grams of carbon dioxide (CO₂).<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,479127,00.html | title=Research reveals environmental impact of Google searches. | accessdate=January 15, 2009 | work=Fox News | date=January 12, 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112195017/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,479127,00.html | archive-date=January 12, 2009 | dead-url=no | df=mdy-all }}</ref> However, Google disputed this figure, arguing instead that a typical search produced only 0.2 grams of CO₂.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2009/01/powering-google-search.html | title=Powering a Google search | accessdate=October 1, 2009 | work=Official Google Blog | publisher=Google | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090729054622/http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2009/01/powering-google-search.html | archive-date=July 29, 2009 | dead-url=no | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====Resource allocation==== {{Main article|Resource allocation}} Algorithms can also be used to route data to data centers where electricity is less expensive. Researchers from MIT, Carnegie Mellon University, and Akamai have tested an energy allocation algorithm that successfully routes traffic to the location with the cheapest energy costs. The researchers project up to a 40 percent savings on energy costs if their proposed algorithm were to be deployed. However, this approach does not actually reduce the amount of energy being used; it reduces only the cost to the company using it. Nonetheless, a similar strategy could be used to direct traffic to rely on energy that is produced in a more environmentally friendly or efficient way. A similar approach has also been used to cut energy usage by routing traffic away from data centers experiencing warm weather; this allows computers to be shut down to avoid using air conditioning.<ref>{{cite web |last= Rear don |first= Marguerite |title= Energy-aware Internet routing coming soon |url= http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-10312408-54.html |date= August 18, 2009 |accessdate= August 19, 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110617075237/http://news.cnet.com/8301-11128_3-10312408-54.html |archive-date= June 17, 2011 |dead-url= no |df= mdy-all }}</ref>
Larger server centers are sometimes located where energy and land are inexpensive and readily available. Local availability of renewable energy, climate that allows outside air to be used for cooling, or locating them where the heat they produce may be used for other purposes could be factors in green siting decisions.
Approaches to actually reduce the energy consumption of network devices by proper network/device management techniques are surveyed in.<ref>{{cite arXiv |author1=Aruna Prem Bianzino |author2=Claude Chaudet |author3=Dario Rossi |author4=Jean-Louis Rougier|title=A Survey of Green Networking Research |arxiv= 1010.3880 |class=cs.NI|date= October 19, 2010 }}</ref> The authors grouped the approaches into 4 main strategies, namely (i) Adaptive Link Rate (ALR), (ii) Interface Proxying, (iii) Energy Aware Infrastructure, and (iv) Max Energy Aware Applications.
====Virtualizing==== {{Main article|Platform virtualization}} {{See also|Comparison of platform virtualization software}} Computer virtualization refers to the abstraction of computer resources, such as the process of running two or more logical computer systems on one set of physical hardware. The concept originated with the IBM [[Mainframe computer|mainframe]] operating systems of the 1960s, but was commercialized for [[x86 architecture|x86]]-compatible computers only in the 1990s. With virtualization, a system administrator could combine several physical systems into virtual machines on one single, powerful system, thereby unplugging the original hardware and reducing power and cooling consumption. Virtualization can assist in distributing work so that servers are either busy or put in a low-power sleep state. Several commercial companies and open-source projects now offer software packages to enable a transition to virtual computing. [[Intel Corporation]] and [[Advanced Micro Devices|AMD]] have also built proprietary [[x86 virtualization#Hardware support|virtualization enhancements]] to the x86 [[instruction set]] into each of their CPU product lines, in order to facilitate virtual computing.
New virtual technologies, such as [[Linux Containers]] can also be used to reduce energy consumption. These technologies make a ore efficient use of resources, thus reducing energy consumption by design. Also, the consolidation of virtualized technologies is more efficient than the one done in [[Virtual machine|virtual machines]], so more services can be deployed in the same physical machine, reducing the amount of hardware needed. <ref>Ismael Cuadrado-Cordero, Anne-Cécile Orgerie, Jean-Marc Menaud., [https://hal-centralesupelec.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01578325v2 “Comparative Experimental Analysis of the Quality-of-Service and Energy-Efficiency of VMs and Containers' Consolidation for Cloud Applications,”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180628233816/https://hal-centralesupelec.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01578325v2 |date=June 28, 2018 }} International Conference on Software, Telecommunications and Computer Networks (SoftCOM 2017), Sep 2017, Split, Croatia. pp.1-6, 2017</ref>
====Terminal servers==== {{Main article|Terminal server}} Terminal servers have also been used in green computing. When using the system, users at a terminal connect to a central server; all of the actual computing is done on the server, but the end user experiences the operating system on the terminal. These can be combined with [[thin client]]s, which use up to 1/8 the amount of energy of a normal workstation, resulting in a decrease of energy costs and consumption.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} There has been an increase in using terminal services with thin clients to create virtual labs. Examples of terminal server software include [[Terminal Services]] for Windows and the [[Linux Terminal Server Project]] (LTSP) for the [[Linux operating system]]. Software-based remote desktop clients such as [[Windows Remote Desktop]] and [[RealVNC]] can provide similar thin-client functions when run on low power, commodity hardware that connects to a server.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://hci.stanford.edu/cstr/reports/2011-02.pdf|title=Software or Hardware: The Future of Green Enterprise Computing|last=Kazandjieva|first=Maria|date=|work=|access-date=|last2=Heller|first2=Brandon|last3=Gnawali|first3=Omprakash|last4=Hofer|first4=Wanja|last5=Levis|first5=Philip|last6=Kozyrakis|first6=Christos|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619190042/http://hci.stanford.edu/cstr/reports/2011-02.pdf|archive-date=June 19, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Power management=== {{Main article|Power management}} The [[Advanced Configuration and Power Interface]] (ACPI), an open industry standard, allows an operating system to directly control the power-saving aspects of its underlying hardware. This allows a system to automatically turn off components such as [[computer display|monitors]] and [[hard drive]]s after set periods of inactivity. In addition, a system may [[Hibernation (computing)|hibernate]], when most components (including the [[Central processing unit|CPU]] and the system RAM) are turned off. ACPI is a successor to an earlier Intel-Microsoft standard called [[Advanced Power Management]], which allows a computer's [[BIOS]] to control power management functions.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}
Some programs allow the user to manually adjust the voltages supplied to the CPU, which reduces both the amount of heat produced and electricity consumed. This process is called [[undervolting]]. Some CPUs can automatically undervolt the processor, depending on the workload; this technology is called "[[SpeedStep]]" on Intel processors, "[[PowerNow!]]"/"[[Cool'n'Quiet]]" on AMD chips, [[LongHaul]] on [[VIA Technologies|VIA]] CPUs, and [[LongRun]] with [[Transmeta]] processors.
====Data center power==== Data centers, which have been criticized for their extraordinarily high energy demand, are a primary focus for proponents of green computing.<ref name="ReferenceGCS9">"[https://www.academia.edu/6982393/Power_Management_Techniques_for_Data_Centers_A_Survey Power Management Techniques for Data Centers: A Survey] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114005435/http://www.academia.edu/6982393/Power_Management_Techniques_for_Data_Centers_A_Survey |date=November 14, 2017 }}", 2014.</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">Kurp, Patrick."Green Computing," ''Communications of the ACM''51(10):11.</ref> According to a [[Greenpeace]] study, data centers represent 21% of the electricity consumed by the IT sector, which is about 382 billion kWh a year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://storage.googleapis.com/p4-production-content/international/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/35f0ac1a-clickclean2016-hires.pdf|title=CLICKING CLEAN: WHO IS WINNING THE RACE TO BUILD A GREEN INTERNET|last=Greenpeace|first=|date=2017|work=|access-date=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180706161712/https://storage.googleapis.com/p4-production-content/international/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/35f0ac1a-clickclean2016-hires.pdf|archive-date=July 6, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Data centers can potentially improve their energy and space efficiency through techniques such as storage consolidation and virtualization. Many organizations are aiming to eliminate underutilized servers, which results in lower energy usage.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://content.dell.com/us/en/enterprise/d/large-business/green-it-over.aspx|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110211120149/http://content.dell.com/us/en/enterprise/d/large-business/green-it-over.aspx|dead-url= yes|archive-date= 11 February 2011|title= Is Green IT Over?|publisher=Dell.com | accessdate=21 November 2007}}</ref> The first step toward this aim will be training of data center administrators.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://sdiwc.net/digital-library/towards-green-computing-application-for-measuring-the-sustainability-of-data-centers-an-analytical-survey.html|title= Towards Green Computing Application for Measuring the Sustainability of Data Centers: An Analytical Survey, Zohreh Gandomi, Salmiah Amin|publisher= SDIWC Digital Library|access-date= November 1, 2014|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150402210100/http://sdiwc.net/digital-library/towards-green-computing-application-for-measuring-the-sustainability-of-data-centers-an-analytical-survey.html|archive-date= April 2, 2015|dead-url= no|df= mdy-all}}</ref> The U.S. federal government has set a minimum 10% reduction target for data center energy usage by 2011.<ref name="ReferenceA" /> With the aid of a self-styled ultraefficient evaporative cooling technology, Google Inc. has been able to reduce its energy consumption to 50% of that of the industry average.<ref name="ReferenceA" />
====Operating system support==== <!-- Needs Mac and Linux coverage. Also, this may be too detailed for a summary--> Microsoft Windows, has included limited [[PC power management]] features since Windows 95.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms810046.aspx |title=Windows 95 Power Management |access-date=April 19, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100311193319/http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms810046.aspx |archive-date=March 11, 2010 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> These initially provided for stand-by (suspend-to-RAM) and a monitor low power state. Further iterations of Windows added hibernate (suspend-to-disk) and support for the [[Advanced Configuration and Power Interface|ACPI]] standard. Windows 2000 was the first NT-based operating system to include power management. This required major changes to the underlying operating system architecture and a new hardware driver model. Windows 2000 also introduced [[Group Policy]], a technology that allowed administrators to centrally configure most Windows features. However, power management was not one of those features. This is probably because the power management settings design relied upon a connected set of per-user and per-machine binary registry values,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liv.ac.uk/csd/greenit/powerdown |title=Windows power-saving options are, bizarrely, stored in HKEY_CURRENT_USER |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127034201/http://www.liv.ac.uk/csd/greenit/powerdown/ |archivedate=November 27, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> effectively leaving it up to each user to configure their own power management settings.
This approach, which is not compatible with Windows Group Policy, was repeated in Windows XP. The reasons for this design decision by Microsoft are not known, and it has resulted in heavy criticism.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2006/11/how_windows_xp.php |title=How Windows XP Wasted $25 Billion of Energy |date=November 21, 2006 |accessdate=November 21, 2005 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061127051214/http://www.treehugger.com/files/2006/11/how_windows_xp.php |archive-date=November 27, 2006 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><!-- this section, while quite possibly true, sounded like OR so I cut it out. In fact, the treehugger source is basically a blog... can we do better? Any mainstream media coverage of criticism for this decision? --> Microsoft significantly improved this in Windows Vista<ref>{{cite web|url=http://download.microsoft.com/download/5/b/9/5b97017b-e28a-4bae-ba48-174cf47d23cd/CPA075_WH06.ppt |title=Windows Vista Power Management Changes |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304110818/http://download.microsoft.com/download/5/b/9/5b97017b-e28a-4bae-ba48-174cf47d23cd/CPA075_WH06.ppt |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }}</ref> by redesigning the power management system to allow basic configuration by Group Policy. The support offered is limited to a single per-computer policy. The most recent release, Windows 7 retains these limitations but does include refinements for [[timer coalescing]], [[processor power management]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/system/pnppwr/powermgmt/ProcPowerMgmtWin7.mspx |title=Windows 7 Processor Power Management |access-date=April 19, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100510015949/http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/system/pnppwr/powermgmt/procpowermgmtwin7.mspx |archive-date=May 10, 2010 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/system/pnppwr/powermgmt/TimerCoal.mspx |title=Windows 7 Timer Coalescing |access-date=April 21, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416215821/http://www.microsoft.com/whdc/system/pnppwr/powermgmt/TimerCoal.mspx |archive-date=April 16, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and display panel brightness. The most significant change in Windows 7 is in the user experience. The prominence of the default High Performance power plan has been reduced with the aim of encouraging users to save power.
There is a significant market in third-party [[PC power management]] software offering features beyond those present in the Windows operating system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.windowsitpro.com/article/buyers-guide/Power-Management-Software-for-Windows-Workstations-Buyers-Guide|title=Power Management Software for Windows Workstations|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426175620/http://www.windowsitpro.com/article/buyers-guide/Power-Management-Software-for-Windows-Workstations-Buyers-Guide|archivedate=April 26, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=power_mgt.pr_power_mgt_comm_packages|title=Energy Star Commercial Packages List|access-date=October 28, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081102002142/https://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=power_mgt.pr_power_mgt_comm_packages|archive-date=November 2, 2008|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hmcsustainability.org.uk/energy.html|author1=The Headmasters'|author2=Headmistresses' Conference|title=HMC: A Practical Guide to Sustainable Building for Schools|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315230900/http://www.hmcsustainability.org.uk/energy.html|archivedate=March 15, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> available. Most products offer [[Active Directory]] integration and per-user/per-machine settings with the more advanced offering multiple power plans, scheduled power plans, anti-insomnia features and enterprise power usage reporting. Notable vendors include [[1E]] NightWatchman,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://itmanagersinbox.com/1399/pc-power-management-solutions |title=PC Power Management Solutions}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://features.techworld.com/green-it/3546/why-use-software-nightwatchman-to-turn-your-pcs-off/ |title=Why use software NightWatchman to turn your PCs off? |access-date=January 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112131522/http://features.techworld.com/green-it/3546/why-use-software-nightwatchman-to-turn-your-pcs-off/ |archive-date=January 12, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Data Synergy [[PowerMAN (Software)]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://projects.oucs.ox.ac.uk/lowcarbonict/conferences/conf-2.htm#providers |title=University of Oxford Low Carbon Project: Energy and the networked computing environment |access-date=January 15, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112091045/http://projects.oucs.ox.ac.uk/lowcarbonict/conferences/conf-2.htm#providers |archive-date=January 12, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.1e.com/Downloads/Articles/Published/451%20-%201E%20-%20Market%20Development-020309.pdf |title=1E upgrades NightWatchman, seeks to bring powermanagement to SMEs: Competitive landscape |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707061543/http://www.1e.com/Downloads/Articles/Published/451%20-%201E%20-%20Market%20Development-020309.pdf |archivedate=July 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[Faronics]] Power Save,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.faronics.com/Faronics/Documents/Study_PowerSave_Forrester_TEI_EN.pdf |title=Forrester Study: Total Economic Impact of Faronics Power Save |access-date=June 9, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203084707/http://faronics.com/faronics/documents/Study_PowerSave_Forrester_TEI_EN.pdf |archive-date=December 3, 2010 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> [[Verdiem]] SURVEYOR and EnviProt Auto Shutdown Manager<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.energystar.gov/ia/products/power_mgt/downloads/Auto_Shutdown_Manager_UC_Berkeley_Case_Study.pdf |title=Going Green: University of California, Berkeley |access-date=April 23, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924001140/http://www.energystar.gov/ia/products/power_mgt/downloads/Auto_Shutdown_Manager_UC_Berkeley_Case_Study.pdf |archive-date=September 24, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Linux]] systems started to provide laptop-optimized power-management in 2005,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/v2.6/snapshots/old/patch-2.6.12-rc5-git10.log |title=Linux 2.6.12-rc5 log with the conservative frequency scaling patches |access-date=February 13, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130629103443/https://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/v2.6/snapshots/old/patch-2.6.12-rc5-git10.log |archive-date=June 29, 2013 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> with power-management options being mainstream since 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.ubuntuusers.de/Strom_sparen/ |title=Strom sparen (in Ubuntu) |access-date=February 13, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214003508/https://wiki.ubuntuusers.de/Strom_sparen/ |archive-date=February 14, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/Power_management |title=Power management (In Gentoo) |access-date=February 13, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170214003243/https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/Power_management |archive-date=February 14, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kde.org/announcements/4.2/|title=KDE 4.2.0 Release Announcement with power management tools|access-date=February 13, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130073644/https://www.kde.org/announcements/4.2/|archive-date=November 30, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
====Power supply==== Desktop [[computer power supply|computer power supplies]] are in general 70–75% efficient,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tomshardware.com/2005/02/28/strong_showing/page38.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121216144500/http://www.tomshardware.com/2005/02/28/strong_showing/page38.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 16, 2012 |title=Strong Showing: High-Performance Power Supply Units |last=Schuhmann |first=Daniel |date=February 28, 2005 |accessdate=September 18, 2007 |publisher=Tom's Hardware }}</ref> dissipating the remaining energy as heat. A certification program called [[80 Plus]] certifies PSUs that are at least 80% efficient; typically these models are drop-in replacements for older, less efficient PSUs of the same form factor. As of July 20, 2007, all new Energy Star 4.0-certified desktop PSUs must be at least 80% efficient.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=computers.pr_crit_computers |title=Computer Key Product Criteria |publisher=Energy Star |accessdate=September 17, 2007 |date=July 20, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928074314/http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=computers.pr_crit_computers |archive-date=September 28, 2007 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
====Storage==== Smaller form factor (e.g., 2.5 inch) [[hard disk drives]] often consume less power per gigabyte than physically larger drives.<ref>{{cite web|title=IS the Silent PC Future 2.5-inches wide?|url=http://www.silentpcreview.com/article145-page1.html|accessdate=August 2, 2008|author=Mike Chin|date=March 8, 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720000101/http://www.silentpcreview.com/article145-page1.html|archive-date=July 20, 2008|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.silentpcreview.com/article29-page2.html|title=Recommended Hard Drives|accessdate=August 2, 2008|author=Mike Chin|date=September 18, 2002|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905085853/http://www.silentpcreview.com/article29-page2.html|archive-date=September 5, 2008|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Unlike hard disk drives, [[solid-state drive]]s store data in flash memory or [[DRAM]]. With no moving parts, power consumption may be reduced somewhat for low-capacity flash-based devices.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://techreport.com/articles.x/10334/13 |title=Super Talent's 2.5" IDE Flash hard drive - The Tech Report - Page 13 |publisher=The Tech Report |date= |accessdate=September 25, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126045422/http://techreport.com/articles.x/10334/13 |archive-date=January 26, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tomshardware.com/reviews/conventional-hard-drive-obsoletism,1324-5.html |title=Power Consumption - Tom's Hardware: Conventional Hard Drive Obsoletism? Samsung's 32 GB Flash Drive Previewed |publisher=Tomshardware.com |date=September 20, 2006 |accessdate=September 25, 2012}}</ref><!-- i-RAM is not SSD. This claim is stating that a 4GB i-RAM consumes more power than a laptop drive. That may be true, but this section is about SSDs -->
In a recent case study, [[Fusion-io]], manufacturer of solid state storage devices, managed to reduce the energy use and operating costs of [[MySpace]] data centers by 80% while increasing performance speeds beyond that which had been attainable via multiple hard disk drives in Raid 0.<ref>{{cite web |author=Media Galleries Temporarily Disabled |url=http://community.fusionio.com/media/p/458/download.aspx |title=Media Galleries Temporarily Disabled - Fusion-io Community Forum |publisher=Community.fusionio.com |date= |accessdate=September 25, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In response, MySpace was able to retire several of their servers.
As hard drive prices have fallen, storage farms have tended to increase in capacity to make more data available online. This includes archival and backup data that would formerly have been saved on tape or other offline storage. The increase in online storage has increased power consumption. Reducing the power consumed by large storage arrays, while still providing the benefits of online storage, is a subject of ongoing research.<ref>[http://searchstorage.techtarget.com/news/1255635/IBM-chief-engineer-talks-green-storage IBM chief engineer talks green storage] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502041656/http://searchstorage.techtarget.com/news/1255635/IBM-chief-engineer-talks-green-storage |date=May 2, 2013 }}, SearchStorage - TechTarget</ref>
====Video card==== A fast [[Graphics processing unit|GPU]] may be the largest power consumer in a computer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xbitlabs.com/articles/video/display/power-noise.html |title=Faster, Quieter, Lower: Power Consumption and Noise Level of Contemporary Graphics Cards |publisher=X-bit labs |date=July 30, 2006 |accessdate=September 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904054636/http://www.xbitlabs.com/articles/video/display/power-noise.html |archivedate=September 4, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Energy-efficient [[video card|display]] options include: * No video card - use a shared terminal, shared [[thin client]], or [[desktop sharing]] software if display required. * Use motherboard video output - typically low 3D performance and low power. * Select a GPU based on low idle power, average wattage, or [[performance per watt]].
====Display==== Unlike other display technologies, [[electronic paper]] does not use any power while displaying an image.<ref>{{Cite journal| last = Heikenfeld | title = A critical review of the present and future prospects for electronic paper | journal = J. Soc. Inf. Display | volume = 19 | issue = 2 | page = 129 | year = 2011 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1889/JSID19.2.129/abstract | doi=10.1889/JSID19.2.129}}</ref> [[CRT monitor]]s typically use more power than LCD monitors. They also contain significant amounts of lead. [[LCD monitor]]s typically use a [[Cold cathode|cold-cathode fluorescent bulb]] to provide light for the display. Some newer displays use an array of [[light-emitting diode]]s (LEDs) in place of the fluorescent bulb, which reduces the amount of electricity used by the display.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.thomasnet.com/fullstory/464080 |title=Cree LED Backlight Solution Lowers Power Consumption of LCD Displays |date=May 23, 2005 |accessdate=September 17, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207075733/http://news.thomasnet.com/fullstory/464080 |archive-date=February 7, 2009 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Fluorescent back-lights also contain mercury, whereas LED back-lights do not.
===Materials recycling=== {{Main article|Electronic waste | computer recycling | Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment Directive}}
Recycling computing equipment can keep harmful materials such as lead, mercury, and hexavalent chromium out of [[landfill]]s, and can also replace equipment that otherwise would need to be manufactured, saving further energy and emissions. Computer systems that have outlived their particular function can be re-purposed, or donated to various charities and non-profit organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://earth911.org/blog/2007/04/12/reuse-your-electronics-through-donation-to-schools-charities-and-nonprofit-organizations/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080503011722/http://earth911.org/blog/2007/04/12/reuse-your-electronics-through-donation-to-schools-charities-and-nonprofit-organizations/ |archivedate=May 3, 2008 |title=Reuse your electronics through donation » Earth 911 |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=April 13, 2010 |accessdate=September 25, 2012}}</ref> However, many charities have recently imposed minimum system requirements for donated equipment.<ref>{{Cite journal |journal=PC Magazine |volume=26 |issue=17 |date=September 4, 2007 |title=15 Ways to Reinvent Your PC |last=Delaney |first=John |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1895,2170255,00.asp |access-date=August 29, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502215811/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,1895,2170255,00.asp |archive-date=May 2, 2008 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Additionally, parts from outdated systems may be salvaged and recycled through certain retail outlets<ref>{{cite web |url=http://investor.staples.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=96244&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1004542&highlight= |title=Staples Launches Nationwide Computer and Office Technology Recycling Program |date=May 21, 2007 |accessdate=September 17, 2007 |publisher=Staples, Inc.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://earth911.org/blog/2007/08/15/goodwill-teams-with-electronic-recyclers-to-recycle-ewaste/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725070137/http://earth911.org/blog/2007/08/15/goodwill-teams-with-electronic-recyclers-to-recycle-ewaste/ |archivedate=July 25, 2008 |title=Goodwill Teams with Electronic Recyclers to Recycle eWaste |date=August 15, 2007 |accessdate=September 17, 2007 |publisher=Earth 911}}</ref> and municipal or private recycling centers. Computing supplies, such as [[Ink cartridges|printer cartridges]], [[paper recycling|paper]], and [[battery recycling|batteries]] may be recycled as well.<ref>[[Ink cartridges#Refilled and 3rd party ink cartridges|Refilled ink cartridges]], [[paper recycling]], [[battery recycling]]</ref>
A drawback to many of these schemes is that computers gathered through recycling drives are often shipped to [[developing countries]] where environmental standards are less strict than in North America and Europe.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Green Tech: Reduce, Reuse, That's It |last=Segan |first=Sascha |journal=PC Magazine |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2704,2183977,00.asp |volume=26 |issue=19 |page=56 |date=October 2, 2007 |accessdate=November 7, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071025050427/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2704,2183977,00.asp |archive-date=October 25, 2007 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The [[Silicon Valley Toxics Coalition]] estimates that 80% of the post-consumer e-waste collected for recycling is shipped abroad to countries such as [[China]] and [[Pakistan]].<ref>{{Cite book |title=Garbage Land: On the Secret Trail of Trash |last=Royte |first=Elizabeth |pages=169–170 |year=2006 |publisher=Back Bay Books |isbn=0-316-73826-3}}</ref>
In 2011, the collection rate of e-waste is still very low, even in the most ecology-responsible countries like France. In this country, e-waste collection is still at a 14% annual rate between electronic equipment sold and e-waste collected for 2006 to 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.greenit.fr/article/materiel/recyclage/deee-l-europe-revoit-ses-objectifs-a-la-hausse-3482 |title=e-waste take-back still very low |date=February 9, 2011 |accessdate=February 9, 2011 |publisher=GreenIT.fr |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110213031911/http://www.greenit.fr/article/materiel/recyclage/deee-l-europe-revoit-ses-objectifs-a-la-hausse-3482 |archive-date=February 13, 2011 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The recycling of old computers raises an important privacy issue. The old storage devices still hold private information, such as emails, passwords, and credit card numbers, which can be recovered simply by someone's using software available freely on the Internet. Deletion of a file does not actually remove the file from the hard drive. Before recycling a computer, users should remove the hard drive, or hard drives if there is more than one, and physically destroy it or store it somewhere safe. There are some authorized hardware recycling companies to whom the computer may be given for recycling, and they typically sign a non-disclosure agreement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mysecurecyberspace.com/articles/features/green-computing-and-privacy-issues.html |title=Green Computing and Privacy Issues |publisher=MySecureCyberspace |date= |accessdate=September 25, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028214220/http://www.mysecurecyberspace.com/articles/features/green-computing-and-privacy-issues.html |archive-date=October 28, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Cloud computing=== {{Main article| Cloud computing }} Cloud computing addresses two major ICT challenges related to Green computing – energy usage and [[resource consumption]]. [[Virtualization]], [[Dynamic provisioning environment]], multi-tenancy, green data center approaches are enabling cloud computing to lower carbon emissions and energy usage up to a great extent. Large enterprises and small businesses can reduce their direct energy consumption and carbon emissions by up to 30% and 90% respectively by moving certain on-premises applications into the cloud.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-backed-research-suggests-big-energy-reductions-from-cloud/ |title= Microsoft-backed research suggests big energy reductions from cloud |publisher= ZDNet |date= November 4, 2010 |accessdate= September 3, 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20151208073045/http://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-backed-research-suggests-big-energy-reductions-from-cloud/ |archive-date= December 8, 2015 |dead-url= no |df= mdy-all }}</ref> One common example includes [[Online shopping]] that helps people purchase products and services over the Internet without requiring them to drive and waste fuel to reach out to the physical shop, which, in turn, reduces greenhouse gas emission related to travel.<ref name="Google Scholar Citations">{{Cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com.pk/citations?view_op=view_citation&hl=en&user=tWRIBtoAAAAJ&sortby=pubdate&citation_for_view=tWRIBtoAAAAJ:rO6llkc54NcC|title=Google Scholar Citations|website=scholar.google.com.pk|access-date=May 5, 2016}}</ref>
===Edge Computing=== {{Main article| Edge computing }} New technologies such as [[Edge computing| Edge]] and [[Fog computing]] are a solution to reducing energy consumption. These technologies allow redistributing computation near the use, thus reducing energy costs in the network.<ref>Cuadrado-Cordero, Ismael, [http://www.theses.fr/2017REN1S003 “Microclouds: an approach for a network-aware energy-efficient decentralised cloud,”] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180628233846/http://www.theses.fr/2017REN1S003 |date=June 28, 2018 }} PhD thesis, 2017.</ref> Furthermore, having smaller data centers, the energy used in operations such as refrigerating and maintenance gets largely reduced.
===Telecommuting=== {{Main article|Telecommuting}} [[Teleconference|Teleconferencing]] and [[telepresence]] technologies are often implemented in green computing initiatives. The advantages are many; increased worker satisfaction, reduction of greenhouse gas emissions related to travel, and increased profit margins as a result of lower overhead costs for office space, heat, lighting, etc.<ref>E. Curry, B. Guyon, C. Sheridan, and B. Donnellan, [http://www.edwardcurry.org/publications/MISQE_SustainableIT_Intel_2012.pdf “Developing an Sustainable IT Capability: Lessons From Intel’s Journey,”] MIS Quarterly Executive, vol. 11, no. 2, pp. 61–74, 2012.</ref> The savings are significant; the average annual energy consumption for U.S. office buildings is over 23 kilowatt hours per square foot, with heat, air conditioning and lighting accounting for 70% of all energy consumed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/cleanenergy/documents/sector-meeting/4bi_officebuilding.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306130237/http://www.epa.gov/cleanenergy/documents/sector-meeting/4bi_officebuilding.pdf |archivedate=March 6, 2009 |format=PDF|title=EPA Office Building Energy Use Profile |date=August 15, 2007 |accessdate=March 17, 2008 |publisher=EPA}}</ref> Other related initiatives, such as [[Hoteling]], reduce the square footage per employee as workers reserve space only when they need it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://energypriorities.com/entries/2007/06/what_is_green_it_data_centers.php|title=What Is Green IT?|access-date=March 17, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415091508/http://energypriorities.com/entries/2007/06/what_is_green_it_data_centers.php|archive-date=April 15, 2008|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Many types of jobs, such as sales, consulting, and field service, integrate well with this technique.
[[Voice over Internet Protocol|Voice over IP (VoIP)]] reduces the telephony wiring infrastructure by sharing the existing Ethernet copper. VoIP and phone extension mobility also made [[hot desking]] more practical.
===Telecommunication network devices energy indices=== The information and communication technologies (ICTs) energy consumption, in the USA and worldwide, has been estimated respectively at 9.4% and 5.3% of the total electricity produced.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.itu.int/ITU-D/cyb/app/docs/itu-icts-for-e-environment.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=July 31, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130507123122/http://www.itu.int/ITU-D/cyb/app/docs/itu-icts-for-e-environment.pdf |archive-date=May 7, 2013 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The energy consumption of ICTs is today significant even when compared with other industries. Some study tried to identify the key energy indices that allow a relevant comparison between different devices (network elements).<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Virgilio |last1=Puglia |title=Energy indices for environmental sustainability |journal=International Journal of Technology Marketing |date=January 2013 |volume=8 |issue=1/2013 |url=http://inderscience.metapress.com/content/n2w5530544110065/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530121855/http://inderscience.metapress.com/content/n2w5530544110065/ |archivedate=May 30, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> This analysis was focused on how to optimise device and network consumption for carrier telecommunication by itself. The target was to allow an immediate perception of the relationship between the network technology and the environmental effect. These studies are at the start and the gap to fill in this sector is still huge and further research will be necessary.
===Supercomputers===
The inaugural [[Green500]] list was announced on November 15, 2007 at SC|07. As a complement to the TOP500, the unveiling of the Green500 ushered in a new era where supercomputers can be compared by performance-per-watt.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.green500.org/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=October 13, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826075608/http://www.green500.org/ |archive-date=August 26, 2016 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The [[Tsubame (supercomputer)|TSUBAME-KFC-GSIC Center]] by Tokyo Institute of Technology, Made in Japan was with a great advantage to the second, the Top 1 Supercomputer in the World with 4,503.17 MFLOPS/W and 27.78 Total Power (kW)++
Today a new supercomputer, [[L-CSC]] from the [[GSI Helmholtz Center]], Made in Germany emerged as the most energy-efficient (or greenest) supercomputer in the world. The L-CSC cluster was the first and only supercomputer on the list to surpass 5 gigaflops/watt (billions of operations per second per watt). L-CSC is a heterogeneous supercomputer that is powered by Dual Intel Xeon E5-260 and GPU accelerators, namely AMD FirePro™ S9150 GPUs. It marks the first time that a supercomputer using AMD GPUs has held the top spot. Each server has a memory of 256 gigabytes. Connected, the server via an Infiniband FDR network.
==Education and certification==
===Green computing programs=== Degree and postgraduate programs that provide training in a range of information technology concentrations along with sustainable strategies in an effort to educate students how to build and maintain systems while reducing its harm to the environment. The [[Australian National University]] (ANU) offers "ICT Sustainability" as part of its information technology and engineering masters programs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://studyat.anu.edu.au/courses/COMP7310;details.html |title=ICT Sustainability Course |date=January 1, 2012 |accessdate=February 5, 2012 |publisher=Australian National University}}</ref> [[Athabasca University]] offer a similar course "Green ICT Strategies",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scis.athabascau.ca/graduate/comp635syllabus.php |title=Green ICT Strategies (Revision 1) |date=September 6, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2012 |publisher=Athabasca University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426013348/http://scis.athabascau.ca/graduate/comp635syllabus.php |archivedate=April 26, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> adapted from the ANU course notes by Tom Worthington.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tomw.net.au/ict_sustainability/ |title=ICT Sustainability: Assessment and Strategies for a Low Carbon Future |date=September 6, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2012 |publisher=Tomw Communications Pty, Limited |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321134527/http://www.tomw.net.au/ict_sustainability/ |archive-date=March 21, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In the UK, [[Leeds Beckett University]] offers an MSc Sustainable Computing program in both full and part-time access modes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://courses.leedsbeckett.ac.uk/sustainablecomputing_msc |title=MSc Sustainable Computing Course |date=January 1, 2012 |accessdate=April 26, 2012 |publisher=Leeds Beckett University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141004083241/http://courses.leedsbeckett.ac.uk/sustainablecomputing_msc |archivedate=October 4, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Green computing certifications=== Some certifications demonstrate that an individual has specific green computing knowledge, including: * Green Computing Initiative - GCI offers the Certified Green Computing User Specialist (CGCUS), Certified Green Computing Architect (CGCA) and Certified Green Computing Professional (CGCP) certifications.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sgauge.com/greenci/ |title=Green Computing Initiative Certification |accessdate=February 5, 2012 |publisher=Green Computing Initiative |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110530000523/http://www.sgauge.com/greenci/ |archive-date=May 30, 2011 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[CompTIA]] Strata Green IT is designed for IT managers to show that they have good knowledge of green IT practices and methods and why it is important to incorporate them into an organization. * [[Information Systems Examination Board]] (ISEB) Foundation Certificate in Green IT is appropriate for showing an overall understanding and awareness of green computing and where its implementation can be beneficial. * [[Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation]] (SiTF) Singapore Certified Green IT Professional is an industry endorsed professional level certification offered with SiTF authorized training partners. Certification requires completion of a four-day instructor-led core course, plus a one-day elective from an authorized vendor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sitf.org.sg/sitfacademy/Programme_SCGP.html |title=Singapore Certified Green IT Professional |year=2012 |accessdate=February 5, 2012 |publisher=Singapore Infocomm Technology Federation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121224193239/http://www.sitf.org.sg/sitfacademy/Programme_SCGP.html |archivedate=December 24, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * [[Australian Computer Society]] (ACS) The ACS offers a certificate for "Green Technology Strategies" as part of the Computer Professional Education Program (CPEP). Award of a certificate requires completion of a 12-week e-learning course designed by Tom Worthington, with written assignments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.acs.org.au/cpeprogram/index.cfm?action=show&conID=greenict |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110302073226/http://www.acs.org.au/cpeprogram/index.cfm?action=show&conID=greenict |archivedate=March 2, 2011 |title=Green Technology Strategies Course |date=November 29, 2011 |accessdate=February 5, 2012 |publisher=Australian Computer Society}}</ref> *International Federation of Global & Green ICT "IFGICT"- promotes Green IT Professional, Certification requires minimum 2 years in ICT industry. IFGICT is shortlisted service provider by UNFCCC - CDM.
===Blogs and Web 2.0 resources=== There are a lot of blogs and other user created references that can be used to gain more insights on green computing strategies, technologies and business benefits. A lot of students in Management and Engineering courses have helped in raising higher awareness about green computing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ygreenit.wordpress.com/about/ |title=Green Computing Blog by students of IE Business School |accessdate=June 12, 2012 |publisher=Wordpress |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322052720/http://ygreenit.wordpress.com/about/ |archive-date=March 22, 2014 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>"http://greenteamforgreenit.blogspot.com.es/ {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313235306/http://greenteamforgreenit.blogspot.com.es/ |date=March 13, 2013 }}" - Green Team for Green IT : A blog by MBA students from IE Business School to spread an understanding on the importance, effects, and implications of Green IT for Business</ref>
===Ratings=== Since 2010, [[Greenpeace]] has maintained a list of ratings of prominent technology companies in several countries based on how clean the energy used by that company is, ranging from A (the best) to F (the worst).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.clickclean.org/ |title=Greenpeace #ClickClean |accessdate=April 26, 2017 |publisher=Greenpeace |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170508054348/http://www.clickclean.org/ |archive-date=May 8, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> This Rating has been certified by Dr. Jordan Kennedy from Cambridge University and his husband Professor Cory Richards. These men have done many years of research towards Green ICT.
==See also== *[[Computational sustainability]] *[[Green information system]] {{Portal|Sustainable development|Energy|Environment}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Camara (charity)]] (Ireland) *''[[Challenging the Chip]]'', a book about labor rights and environmental justice in the global electronics industry *[[Desktop virtualization]] *[[Data migration]] *[[Digger gold]] *[[e-cycling]] *[[eDay]], an electronic waste collection day in New Zealand *[[California Electronic Waste Recycling Act]] *[[Energy Efficient Ethernet]] *[[Energy use in the United States#Energy consumption of computers in the USA|Energy consumption of computers in the USA]] * [[IEEE 1680]] *[[Interconnect bottleneck]] *[[IT energy management]] *[[Minimalism (computing)]] *[[Optical communication]] *[[Optical fiber cable]] *[[Optical interconnect]] *[[Parallel optical interface]] *[[Plug computer]] *[[Power factor]] *[[Power usage effectiveness]] (PUE) *[[Rebound effect (conservation)|Rebound effect]] (paradoxical negative effect) *[[Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive]] (RoHS) *[[Standby power]] *[[Sustainable Electronics Initiative]] (SEI) *[[Time-sharing]] *[[Thunderbolt (interface)]] *[[Virtual application]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120426151931/http://css.snre.umich.edu/css_doc/CSS09-07.pdf Green IT Factsheet] by the [[University of Michigan]]'s [http://www.css.snre.umich.edu/ Center for Sustainable Systems] *[http://www.ifgict.org IFG International Federation of Green ICT Standard]
